thesis.description: The study on *Case Work with Single Women in a Psychiatric Setting, was undertaken in the Social Service Department of the Allan Memorial Institute of Psychiatry. This study set out to find the nature and effectiveness of case work help in returning to the acommunity a better adjusted person. The study involved the analysis of thirty-five social service records on single women between the ages of sixteen and forty-five years.[...]
thesis.creator: Shaw, F.
thesis.subject: Social Work.
thesis.title: Case Work With Single Women in a Psychiatric Setting.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The greatest Teacher of all approached the problems of humanity in two distinct ways.In the first place,He used the traditional method of preaching;in the second place,he met the needs of mankind by various forms of personal service.In His own words,He defined these two approaches to life's problems as follows, "I am marked out by the spirit of the Lord to give good news to the poor; He has sent Me to make well those who are broken-hearted,to say that the prisoners will be let go, and the blind will see, and to make the wounded free from their chains."[...]
thesis.creator: Saunders, Thomas.
thesis.subject: Student activities.
Youth.
School superintendents.
thesis.title: The extracurricular interests and responsibilities of a city principal with reference to the welfare and development of the pupil in the community.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Although the products of the metabolism of the adrenal cortical steroids have not been definitely established, two groups of urinary substances are believed to be derived from the adrenocortical hormones. These are the cortically active material present in lipid extracts of urine and the urinary 17-ketosteroids. Almost nothing is known of the chemical nature, or of the adrenal precursors, of the urinary corticoids; and although the chemical identity of the 17-keto- steroids has been largely elucidated, their precursors are also unknown. [...]
thesis.creator: Saffran, J.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Studies on the metabolism of steroid hormones.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Is it possible to correlate the source of an Aerobacter strain with some biochemical property? An answer to this question would be of value in the bacteriological analysis of water and soil for fecal contamination. It would also be valuable in medical bacteriology to differentiate intestinal forms from those derived from soil and water on uncooked foods. At present, water is oondemned by public health authorities on the basis of the presence of any member of the coliform group. Standard Methods (1946) defines the coliform thus; nIt is recommended that the coliform group be considered to include all aerobic and facultative anaerobic gram-negative non-spore-forming bacilli which ferment lactose with gas formation."[...]
thesis.creator: Ruyter, S.A.
thesis.subject: Bacteriology.
thesis.title: A comparative study of strains of Aerobacter isolated from different sources.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Most investigations with radio frequency electrical fields have dealt with their effect on physical properties of molecules, but only a few studies have been made to determine whether they could affect chemical reactivity and these report conflicting results. In an effort to settle the question, Bryce (1) and Genge (2) investigated the effect of radio frequency fields on the catalyzed and uncatalyzed polymerization of styrene. The problem dealt with in the present thesis is an outcome of their work. [...]
thesis.creator: Russell, Stewart Henry.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The effect of high frequency electrical fields on the decomposition of benzoyl peroxide.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The neutron current and density of a uniform neutron stream may be determined by inserting a disc-shaped neutron detector at right angles to the direction of the stream and measuring the activities induced over the front and back surfaces of the detector. The sum of these two activities will be referred to as simply the "activity" of the detector. [...]
thesis.creator: Routly, Paul McRae.
thesis.subject: Mathematics.
thesis.title: The influence of a thick neutron detector on the distribution of neutrons in a uniform neutron stream.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Trichinosis as a human disease has its roots in antiquity, but no positive knowledge of the nature of the disease was obtained until the 19th Century, with the discovery of the worm itself by James Paget, a first-year medical student at St. Bartholomew's Hospital, London. This discovery laid the foundation for further investigation, until finally, the life-cycle of the causative organism, Trichinella spiralis, a parasitic nematode, was elucidated, and possible means of control and diagnostic techniques developed. Although the serological aspects of Trichinosis have been investigated extensively, it was felt that there still existed a need for further information on the value of the complement-fixation test as an early diagnostic measure. [...]
thesis.creator: Ross, Winifred Margaret.
thesis.subject: Parasitology.
thesis.title: Serological studies in trichinosis in experimental animals.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: As early as 1877 Pasteur noticed inhibition of the growth of the anthrax bacillus by certain air-borne contaminants and two years later DeBary emphasized the significance of the antagonistic interrelations among microorganisms. At about the same time another worker (87) noticed that certain bacteria disappeared much more rapidly in unsterilized soils then in sterilized soils, and it was even suggested that the substances produced by the dominant organism might be of use in the control of bacterial infections. [...]
thesis.creator: Rockwell, Keith Redden.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Bacteriology.
thesis.title: The production of antibiotic substances by a group of microorganisms with special reference to those active against gram negative bacteria.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The Helminthosporium diseases of cereals have been receiving an increasing amount of attention during the past twenty-five years* This has been due to a more general realization that these diseases cause important losses every year in the grain growing areas of the world. In a pamphlet Issued by the Dominion Laboratories of Plant Pathology in 1933, it is stated that In Manitoba and Saskatchewan alone the loss from root rot caused by Helmintho sp orium sativum P.K. and B. amounts to millions of dollars annually. Machacek in 1943 concluded from the results of a three-year survey in Manitoba that this root rot causes a loss of about 12% of the wheat and barley crop in that province each year. [...]
thesis.creator: Robinson, Dean Boundy.
thesis.subject: Agronomy.
thesis.title: Studies on barley diseases caused by helminthosporium sativum P.K. & B.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: At the present time all known methods for the hydrolysis of proteins are subject to serious limitations. Enzymatic hydrolysis is slow and incomplete, alkalis racemize the optically active amino acids and destroy cystine and arginine, and acid hydrolysis is accompanied by humin formation and tryptophane destruction. The destruction of tryptophane during acid hydrolysis is not, in all cases, due to the direct action of the acid since pure tryptophane is relatively stable in hot dilute sulphuric and hydrochloric acids. The destruction must, therefore, be due to some other constituent or constituents of the protein. Consequently, there is some reasonable prospect that tryptophane destruction can be avoided if the harmful effects of these other agents can be eliminated. [...]
thesis.creator: Rigby, Francis Lloyd.
thesis.subject: Agricultural Chemistry.
thesis.title: Studies on acid hydrolysis of proteins.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Chromite has long been considered as one of the more important strategic raw materials. Its indispensability in the manufacture of alloys makes it vital to the nation's industrial life. The great bulk of the mineral is consumed in the form of ferrochrome, an alloy containing 60 to 70 per cent chromium, which is used in making alloy steels. Pre-war time specifications for ferrochromium required that it should contain 68 to 69 per cent chromium. Since 194l these specifications have been lowered to between 60 and 63 per cent chromium so that low-grade ores could be utilized. [...]
thesis.creator: Raju, B. Sada Siva.
thesis.subject: Mining Engineering.
thesis.title: Concentration of low-grade chromite ores.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: As the pulsating jet engine has been accorded little publicity in any respect apart from its notorious use as a prime mover for the "V-l" type of missile, its mode of operation may be relatively unfamiliar to those well acquainted both with the conventional forms of internal combustion engines and with the more widely employed turbo-jet. Accordingly, there follows a brief description of this engine and its mode of operation. Basically, the engine consists of a shaped metal tube fitted with one-way flow check valves at the forward or "intake" end. [...]
thesis.creator: Quinn, Hubert Frederick.
thesis.subject: Physics.
thesis.title: The spectrophotometric determination of exhaust gas temperatures in the pulsating jet engine.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The importance of preparing hormonal steroids containing an isotopic carbon atom has been well recognized. As the metabolism of these substances is still poorly understood, the tracer technique should become a very useful tool to elucidate the pathways of the steroid hormones in the animal organism. We have been concerned with the problem of preparing labelled steroidal compounds in this laboratory. The main idea has been to open one of the rings in the steroid nucleus, introduce an isotopic carbon atom and regenerate the original steroid molecule for subsequent use. Among the four rings of the steroid molecule, ring A seemed to be the most desirable for this purpose because several important hormonal steroids, namely, testosterone, progesterone and corticoid hormones, possess a common ^3 unsaturated ketone group in ring A; thus a general method of labelling these steroids was sought.[...]
thesis.creator: Prado, Eline Sant’Anna.
thesis.subject: Biochemistry.
thesis.title: Oxidation studies of the steroid ring A.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: On all sides, one hears appeals to objectivity and exhortations to be objective. These admonitions are usually made by scientifically-minded people. Laudable as these appeals may be, they are sometimes so framed as to give the impression that objectivity is a quality or property of events that is immediately recognizable. It is thus, a finality, an ultimate for knowledge, which, when recognized, is taken as given. Ulterior questions, as to what constitutes the objective character of fact, are considered spurious meanderings of minds intent on weaving a cosy scheme of the universe.[...]
thesis.creator: Polonoff, I.I.
thesis.subject: Philosophy.
thesis.title: Objectivity and its relation to physical science.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Bone formation may be studied from two different aspects; the morphological, which reveals the existence of various modes of ossification, and the biochemical, which shows the deposition of calcium phosphate in all types of bones and teeth. The correlation of morphological and biochemical findings has been hailed as the way to an understanding of where and how the salts coming from the blood are deposited in the growing bone. (Policard and Roche). This information is important not only for the deeper understanding of ossification, but also for the knowledge of fracture healing, rickets, and other bone disturbances.[...]
thesis.creator: Percival, W.L.
thesis.subject: Experimental surgery.
thesis.title: Rapid exchange of bone salts in the skeleton of newborn animals as shown by an improved autographic technique.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The increasing utilization of higher frequencies and pulsed techniques in radio engineering requires the re-examination of the behaviour under these conditions of the individual circuit components. This thesis deals with the frequency characteristics of fixed composition type resistors (both the carbon rod and metallized film type) such as are commonly used in radio and allied apparatus. The phenomenon of the decrease in resistance with increasing frequency is investigated theoretically and experimentally. The equivalent circuit of the resistor at high frequencies is determined by measurement. The effect of the frequency characteristic on the power dissipated by a resistor under pulsed conditions is theoretically examined.[...]
thesis.creator: Pavlasek, Tomas Jan Frantisek.
thesis.subject: Electrical Engineering.
thesis.title: Characteristics of composition type resistores.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: It is an obvious and well-known fact among urban dwellers, that the two main physical problems in central areas of cities - traffic congestion and the lack of sun, light and open space - are caused by the overcrowding of land by buildings and an archaic traffic system. In these areas, where high building density prevails, the design and siting of buildings closely controls the amount of natural light which has access to them. Before the advent of elevators, the height of buildings was fairly limited by various practical considerations, such as, the number of flights of stairs which people could reasonably be expected to climb.[...]
thesis.creator: Papanek, R.
thesis.subject: Architecture.
thesis.title: Methods of control of the bulk and form of buildings in the central area of cities, with reference to Montreal.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: [...] The Italo-Turklsh War was singular in many respects. Although most of the fighting took place in Africa the real importance of the war lay in its effect upon European politics. Because of Italy's naval superiority the Turkish forces in Africa could not be reinforced, with the result that the two opponents could not actually come to grips with one another. It became a war which was at once half European and half colonial, and one in which no decisive battle could be fought between the belligerents. The question posed by this war was not who would possess Tripoli, but rather, what would the effect of the war be upon Italy, upon Turkey, and upon European politics in general. [...]
thesis.creator: O’Neill, T. L. B.
thesis.subject: World War, 1914-1918 -- Diplomatic history.
Great Britain -- Foreign relations -- Italy.
Turkey -- Foreign relations -- Great Britain.
thesis.title: British policy in the Italo-Turkish war.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: Platonic Philosophy as a whole is a movement upwards. It is the approach to an ideal, to an absolute end which exists of its own right. It does not offer a system in which all the component ideas are located in a specific place, and it does not force us to study these separately and then bring them together into an artificial whole. We can consider Plato's Philosophy from different points of view: his Ethics, his Epistemology, or his Politics, but every one of these points of view is so concerned and intermingled with the rest that an isolation of one of them is, strictly speacking, impossible. [...]
thesis.creator: Oduber-Quiros, Daniel.
thesis.subject: Plato.
thesis.title: Plato’s dialectic, as developed through his ethics, epistomology and ontology.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The presence of boron in plants was first recorded by Mittstein and Apoiger in 1857, who were able to find boric acid in the ash of seeds of Maesa picta, an Abyssinian plant belonging to the order Myrsinaceae. More recent workers have shown that boron occurs in small proportions in the ash of many kinds of plants. In 1910 Agulhon published results of experiments showing increase in dry weight, over that of control without boron, of wheat, oats, and radish grown in sand cultures with 0.5 mg. of boron per kg. of sand.[...]
thesis.creator: Nussey, Albert Norris.
thesis.subject: Horticulture-Botany.
thesis.title: Some effects on boron on the rooting of softwood cuttings.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: During the past twenty-five years the wheat stem sawfly, Cephus cinctus Nort., has become one of the worst pests of wheat in the prairie provinces. Annual losses in the wheat-growing area of Saskatchewan have been estimated at up to seventeen million busheis (Farstad, 1945). This would seem to indicate inadequate natural control. There are, however, several native parasites of this pest, and of these Microbracon cephi Gahan is the most important. In some areas this parasite has been very effective in reducing severe sawfly infestations.[...]
thesis.creator: Nelson, William Arnold.
thesis.subject: Entomology.
thesis.title: The biology of Microbracon Cephi Gahan, an important native parasite of the wheat stem sawfly, Cephus Cinctus Nort.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: A digestibility study was conducted in which an identical diet was fed to five species, namely, rats, pigs, sheep, guinea pigs and humans. The diet consisted mainly of whole wheat. As fed, it was found to be unsuitable for digestibility studies with guinea pigs. With sheep, a basal hay diet was fed and digestion coefficients determined indirectly. Variability between individuals was relatively low, for all species, for food fractions other than crude fiber and ether extract. Humans digested crude fiber to the same extent as pigs and rata. The range of the digestion coefficients for crude protein, nitrogen-free extract and digestible energy was remarkably small, considering that the species used in this study had anatomically different digestive systems. All species showed significant differences in the total digestible nutrients and digestible energy of the diet. Further research is needed in comparative species digestibility studies with humans.
thesis.creator: Neilson, Helen Ridout.
thesis.subject: Nutrition.
thesis.title: A study of the apparent digestibility of identical diets by different species.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The seed hairs of the typha family (cat-tails) are easy to collect and appear to the eye to consist of cellulosic fibers of nearly uniform length radiating from a central stem. The object of the present Thesis was to review the literature concerning the chemistry and possible uses of the typha plant and to Supplement existing knowledge concerning the chemical composition and properties of the seed hairs. It was found that Standard methods of wood analyses gave inconsistent results with typha seed hairs and an effort was made to discover why such methods were unsuitable in this particular case.
thesis.creator: Narasimhan, Ramanuja Iyengar.
thesis.subject: Chemistry.
thesis.title: The analysis of the typha latifolia linn. seed hairs.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: This thesis is composed of four chapters, each dealing with a separate problem related to surgery of the heart and lungs. The work was performed in the Departments of Experimental Surgery and Physiology at McGill University. In Chapter I, a description is given of a new method of preparing dogs for the study of metabolism. As will be pointed out, such preparations need not be restricted to this study but can be used to investigate several other problems. A review of the literature dealing with the bronchial vessels, as outlined in Chapter 2, emphasizes their importance to the physiology of respiration. It was felt, therefore, that it would be interesting to attempt to obliterate this vascular supply to one lung in dogs and to study the effect histologically. [...]
thesis.creator: Murphy, D.R.
thesis.subject: Experimental Surgery.
thesis.title: Investigations dealing with surgery of the heart and lungs in experimental animals.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.

thesis.description: The sedimentary, volcanic and intrusive rocks of an area in the northern part of the Canadian Shield are described. Particular reference is made to the relative ages of these formations* their structures, and to major faults. The field evidence suggests that a red feldsparporphyry intrusive is younger than the granite which intrudes the volcanic porphyries. This, and to some extent the stratigraphic sequence proposed differ from previous findings. The distribution and attitudes of the sedimentary and volcanic formations indicate a flexure in a regional northv/esterly-trending open fold- Two sets of right-hand faults strike northerly and northeasterly respectively. The latter are marked by large displacements and in places by giant quartz veins. The horizontal movement along one such northeasterly-trending fault is determined as three to four miles. The age relations and causes of faulting are discussed.
thesis.creator: Mulligan, Robert.
thesis.subject: Geological Science.
thesis.title: Geology of the northern part of the east shore of Great Bear Lake, N.W.T.
thesis.rights: All items in eScholarship@McGill are protected by copyright with all rights reserved unless otherwise indicated.
